document: Conducting Anilate-Based Mixed-Valence Fe(II)Fe(III) Coordination Polymer: Small-polaron Hopping Model for Oxalate-Type Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D Networks

QnA.question: What is the empirical formula of the mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer discussed in the document?
What type of ligand is used in the synthesis of the mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer?
QnA.answer: The ligand used is chlorocyanoanilate dianionic ligand (ClCNAn2–).

QnA.question: What is the role of the TAG cation in the structure of the mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer?
QnA.answer: The TAG cation imposes its C3 symmetry to the structure and engages in intermolecular N–H···Cl hydrogen bonding with the ligand.

QnA.question: What is the magnetic ordering temperature of the mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer?
QnA.answer: The magnetic ordering occurs below 4 K.

QnA.question: True or False: The mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer shows semiconducting behavior with higher in-plane conductivity compared to perpendicular conductivity.
What model is applied to explain the conductivity of the anilate-based systems compared to the oxalate ones?
QnA.answer: A small-polaron hopping model is applied.

QnA.question: True or False: The Fe(II) and Fe(III) ions in the mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer are spatially distributed and disordered over two crystallographically independent sites.
What is the significance of the TAG cation in the development of multifunctional binuclear/bimetallic transition metal or lanthanide coordination polymers?
QnA.answer: The TAG cation's ability to crystallize in polar space groups and engage in hydrogen bonding may lead to multifunctional properties, possibly including multiferroic properties.

QnA.question: True or False: The mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) 2D coordination polymer based on the asymmetric chloro-cyanoanilate ligand crystallizes in the polar noncentrosymmetric space group P3.
What is the impact of the bridging ligand on the electron transport mechanism in mixed-valence Fe(II)Fe(III) coordination polymers?
QnA.answer: The nature of the bridging ligand, such as its ability for electron delocalization, significantly impacts the electron transport mechanism, with anilate-based ligands promoting better electron delocalization compared to oxalate-based ligands.
